title-group.article-title: A new approach for loads moving on infinite beams resting on elastic foundation

article-meta.aff: National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece

author-notes.corresp: Ioannis G Raftoyiannis, Laboratory of Steel Structures, Department of Civil Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Iroon Polytechneiou Str., Zografou Campus, Athens 15780, Greece Email: rafto@central.ntua.gr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The present work deals with the problem of the dynamic behavior of infinite beams resting on a Winkler-type elastic foundation under moving loads. The beam is subjected to a moving point load traveling with constant speed. Determining the effective length of the beam for a non-moving (static) load, and using the so-called quasi-stationary state of the beam, a solution is proposed with the aid of modal analysis and useful conclusions are obtained. Moving loads have a significant influence on the dynamic behavior of elastic or inelastic solid elements of an entire structure or parts of the structure, while they may produce strong vibrations on such systems, especially when high speeds are reached. The expressions obtained in this work allow the use of the same formulae for any values of speed or damping parameters. The analytical results obtained by the relations presented herein are compared to the ones given by Frýba in the relative chapter of his classic work. Finally, the possible speeds of moving loads that can be reached in the case of such types of beams are estimated and the application field of the gathered relations is determined.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Moving loads have a significant influence on the dynamic behavior of elastic or inelastic solid elements, of an entire structure, or parts of a structure, while they may produce strong vibrations of such systems, especially in the high speeds spectra. The problem of finite beams under the action of a moving load has already been solved employing a number of methods, among which the modal superposition technique dominates. The aforementioned method, that is as a matter of fact a Fourier analysis, is highly effective for moving loads with low speeds.

Although Fourier analysis is highly effective at low speeds of moving loads, at high speeds it is necessary to take into account a fairly large number of terms in the series (Frýba, 1972). This, in combination with modern computers, is possible and easy.

A special category, among the problems involving moving loads, is the case of a load moving along an infinite beam resting on an elastic foundation. This type of problem is of great theoretical and practical significance. It is clear that the main factor, which drastically affects the problem, is the validity of the foundation model. The soil can be modeled by foundation models such as the Winkler’s model (with one parameter) or another one with two parameters (Pasternak, 1954), that includes the shear parameter influence or by higher order models, that include the influence of some secondary parameters. It has been proved (Mallik et al., 2006) that the effect of various models on the foundation behavior is insignificant, except in the case of a semi-infinite elastic medium, where the wave field including surface waves does affect the response of the beam.

Timoshenko (1926) was the first to solve the case of a constant load moving on an infinite beam on an elastic foundation. The above problem was theoretically refined by Dörr (1948) regarding the transient phenomenon. Later, Kenney (1954) dealt with the problem from the same point of view but included the effect of damping. Mathews (1959) studied the problem of an infinite beam on an elastic foundation under a harmonic load with constant speed, and Goloskokov and Fillipov (1962) studied the case of a spring mass with two harmonic loads. Frýba (1957) solved the general case of an infinite beam on an elastic foundation under a load generally varying in time through an approximate method. From the closed form solution, distinct differences can be obtained among the responses in the subcritical, critical and supercritical cases. For load speeds lower than the critical one, the largest amplitude of the wave occurs near the point of loading, while for load speeds higher than the critical one, the waves move ahead of the load and their amplitude is smaller than those following the load. Sun (2001) presented a closed form solution for the response of a beam lying on a Winkler-type foundation subjected to a moving line-load, by means of a two-dimensional Fourier transform and employing Green’s functions. The problem is studied for the damped case at subcritical speeds. Many researchers have also studied the above problem using the Finite Elements Method. Among them, the significant study of Frýba et al. (1993) must be mentioned.

The solution to such problems of infinite beams is generally not expressed in a series. An attempt to reconcile the above two basic methods of solution has been made by Steele (1967), who used the Poisson’s summation formula.

The present work deals with the aforementioned problem and attempts a solution using the modal superposition technique. The expressions obtained in this study are given in a general form that can be employed for any value of speed or damping parameters. The results gathered by the expressions obtained herein are compared to the ones presented by Frýba (1972) in the relative chapter of his classic textbook. Finally, the possible range of speeds for moving loads that may appear in the case of such a beam is estimated, and the application field of the gathered relations is determined.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical formulation
sec.p:
The problem will be formulated as follows: The infinite beam in Figure 1 is subjected to a concentrated load P moving with a constant speed υ. The beam is made from a homogeneous and isotropic material with modulus of elasticity E and is resting on an elastic foundation. The elastic foundation is assumed to be of the Winkler type, i.e., the foundation reactions are directly proportional to the deflections of the beam. Figure 1.
Moving load on an infinite beam resting on an elastic foundation.

According to the above assumptions, the transverse vibration of the beam is governed by the following differential equation: (1)EIw″+cw·+mw··+kw=P·δ(x-υt) where c is the damping coefficient, k is the Winkler foundation coefficient, υ is the speed of the load, and δ is the Dirac-delta function.

For the above problem, the so-called quasi-stationary state exists in which the beam is at rest relatively to a coordinate system moving with the same speed υ as the moving load (Frýba, 1972). This state is valid after a sufficiently long time of load travel (otherwise it is no longer time dependent) and thus, it depends only on the distance from the origin of the coordinate axes. With these assumptions and assuming that the load P affects at each time only a length 2L of the beam depending on the beam’s and foundation’s characteristics, the focus is on studying the dynamic behavior of a random point A of the beam (see Figure 2) for different positions of the moving load P, considering that the moving load P passes over a finite beam with length 2L and constant speed υ. Figure 2.
Dynamical response of a point A of the beam.

Hence, the following cases:
For α > L: the point A is not yet affected by the load P (see Figure 2(a))
For α < L: the point A oscillates and the deflection is wA (see Figure 2(b))
For α > L: the point A vibrates freely (wA≠0). (see Figure 2(c)).
Thus, the influence length (2L), through studying the static problem must first be determined.

sec.title: 3. The static problem
sec.p:
It is obvious that the problem of an infinite beam can be studied through observing that of a semi-infinite beam with half the load P (see Figure 3). Figure 3.
Symmetry conditions of the problem.
The governing equation for the static problem of a semi-infinite beam is: (2)EIw″+kw=0
The solution of the above equation is: (3)w(x)=eλx(c1sinλx+c2cosλx) +e-λx(c3sinλx+c4cosλx) with λ4=k4EJ
The boundary conditions of the problem are: (4)w(∞)=w'(∞)=w″(∞)=w″'(∞)=0w'(0)=0EIw″'(0)=P2
From equations (4), and because of equation (3), the following is obtained: (5)c1=c2=0c3=c4c3=P8EIλ3
Therefore, the solution of equation (2) is readily obtained: (6)w(x)=P8EIλ3·e-λ·x(sinλx+cosλx)

Let the next focus be into equation (6). Applying the above equation, the gathered deflection diagrams have the form shown in Figure 4(a). Through a numerical application of equation (6), it is concluded that the following equality is valid with a satisfactory accuracy: (7)ℓ1≅ℓ2 Figure 4.
Determination of length L using the lengths ℓ1andℓ2.

Indeed, applying, for example, the above-mentioned equation for E = 2.1 x 107 kN/m2, k = 60 kN/m, I = 0.01 m4, and P = 1, the plot of Figure 4(b) is obtained, from which: ℓ1=ℓ2≅26m. From this Figure it can be seen that the load P affects only the zone 2L, while beyond this zone the action of the load is indeed negligible.

The length L can be determined, observing that the quantity ℓ1=(L/2) is the length at which w(ℓ1)=0, which means that: sinλℓ1+cosλℓ1=0, or sin2λℓ1+cos2λℓ1+2·sinλℓ1·cosλℓ1=0 or, sin2λℓ1=-1=sin3π2 and, finally: (8)L=2·ℓ1=3π2λ=3π2·4EJk4
In the next sections, the accuracy of the above relation is evaluated.

sec.title: 4. The vibration of the finite beam
sec.p:
Let the infinite beam shown in Figure 5 now be considered. It is resting on a Winkler-type foundation with constant k. In addition, to be considered is a part (ab) of the above beam with length ℓ=2L that is determined using equation (8). Figure 5.
Finite beam with length ℓ = 2L resting on an elastic foundation.

sec.title: 4.1. The free vibration case
sec.p: Equation (1), when setting P = 0, becomes: (9)EIw″″+c·w·+m·w··+k·w=0
Solutions of separate variables of the form are being sought: (10)w(x,t)=Xn(x)·Tn(t)
Thus, equation (9) gives: (11)EIX″″n-(mωn 2-k)Xn=0T··n+cmT·n+ωn 2Tn=0

By setting: (12)μ4=mωn 2-kEI there is the case of a free vibrating beam with length ℓ, on an elastic foundation, whose shape functions, eigenfrequencies, and time functions are: (13)Xn=sinnπxℓTn(t)=e-β·t(Ansinω¯nt+Bncosω¯nt) where ωn=n4π4EImℓ4+km,β=c2m,ω¯n=ωn 2-β2
The term n4π4EImℓ4 is the spectrum of eigenfrequencies of the one-span simply supported beam.

sec.title: 4.2. The forced vibration case
sec.p: Considering that time t starts the instant when point A begins to vibrate, there are the following two time intervals (see also Figure 2):

sec.title: 4.2.1. Time interval 10≤t≤ℓ/υ
sec.p: The equation of the problem is: (14)EIw″″+cw·+mw··+kw=P·δ(x-υt)

A solution under the following form is sought: (15)w(x,t)=∑nXn(x)·Φn(t) with Xn from equation (13) and Φn the time function to be determined. Introducing equation (15) into equation (14), the following is obtained: EI∑nX″″nΦn+c∑nXnΦ·n+m∑nXnΦ··n +k∑nXnΦn=P·δ(x-υt) and since Xn satisfies equation (11) for the free vibration case, there follows: m∑nωn 2XnΦn+c∑nXnΦ·n+m∑nXnΦ··n =P·δ(x-υt)

Multiplying the above equation by Xn, integrating the outcome from 0 to ℓ, and taking into account the orthogonality condition, the following equation is obtained: (16)Φ··n+cm·Φ·n+ωn 2·Φn=2Pmℓ·sinΩnt where Ωn=nπυℓ
The solution of equation (16) is given by the second Duhamel’s integral, as following: (17)Φn(t)=2Pmℓω¯n·∫0 te-β(t-τ)·sinΩnτ·sinω¯n(t-τ)dτ with βandω¯n given by equation (13).
Carrying out the above integration, the following is finally obtained: (18)Φn(t)=2Pmℓ·1ω¯n 4+2(β2-ω¯n 2)Ωn 2+Ωn 4
Thus, the deformed state is: (19)w(x,t)=∑nXn(x)Φn(t)

sec.title: 4.2.2. Time interval 2: t≥ℓ/υ = to
sec.p: For t≥ℓ/υ, the point A (Figure 2(c)) continues to vibrate performing a free vibration. From equation (15), is obtained: (20)wf(x,t)=∑ne-β(t-to)·[Ansinω¯n(t-to) +Bncosω¯n(t-to)]·sinnπxℓ where An and Bn are constants determined by the time conditions at t = to.
At this instant, the deformations and the speeds of the deformations, given by equations (18) and (20), must be equal.
Therefore: Bn=Φn(to),and-β·Bn+ω¯n·An=Φ·n(to), and finally: (21)An=Φ·n(to)+βΦn(to)ω¯nBn=Φn(to)
Usually, the above equations (18), (20) and (21) are expressed in dimensionless form. The dimensional form is proceeded with, in order to maintain realistic conditions and behavior of the beam cases.

Moreover, it is desirable to have the possibility to evaluate whether a theoretically right situation is possible or not to be met in practice. Many times, situations and conditions that do not exist or are impossible to fulfill, are discussed and analyzed being practically meaningless.

sec.title: 5. Numerical results and discussion
sec.p:
In order to study a broad range of types of soils and beams, the property data presented in the first two lines of Table 1 will be considered, and in particular soils of grid (sand-gravel), sand soils, and argil-sand soils. Table 1.
Critical speeds of a simply supported beam and a beam on elastic foundation
Beam EI (Nm2) m (kg/m) 200 × 107 30 20 × 107 120 0.2 × 107 30
Soil Es (N/m2) k (N/m) Grit 1.5 × 108 2 × 107 Sand 0.3 × 108 0.4 × 107 Argil sand 0.03 × 108 0.04 × 107 Grit 1.5 × 108 2 × 107 Sand 0.3 × 108 0.4 × 107 Argil sand 0.03 × 108 0.04 × 107 Grit 1.5 × 108 2 × 107 Sand 0.3 × 108 0.4 × 107 Argil sand 0.03 × 108 0.04 × 107
Equivalent length 42.15 63.03 112.08 23.70 35.44 63.02 7.49 11.21 19.93
υcr (km/h) 1385 926 521 389 260 146 246 164 92
υcr (km/h) 4157 2780 1563 1169 782 439 739 494 278
Keeping in mind that the effect of difference in the foundation modeling is not significant (Mallik et al., 2006), a Winkler-type soil is considered.
The constant k is obtained (Pasternak, 1954) using the relation k=EsH(1+νs)(1-2νs) for a constant thickness of the soil layer H≅12m and a Poisson’s ratio νs=0.25.

The beam with EI = 200 × 107 Nm2 and m = 30 kg/m corresponds to a steel profile (HE-M 1000), the beam with EI = 20 × 107 Nm2 and m = 120 kg/m to a concrete beam with cross-section area A = 0.5 m2, and the beam with EI = 0.2 × 107 Nm2 and m = 30 kg/m to a concrete beam with cross-section area A = 1.0 × 0.125 m2.

sec.title: 5.1. Reaching the critical speed
sec.p: Critical speed is the one by which the vehicle crosses the beam in time equal to the fundamental semi-period and equivalent length is the corresponding length of the beam. In the fourth line of Table 1 can be seen the corresponding critical speeds of a simply-supported single-span beam not resting on soil (that can serve for instance as a one-span bridge), and with a span length equal to the equivalent length (third line) of the beam under study resting on an elastic foundation, in order for us to compare the critical speeds of the other cases to be compared with this one.

In the fifth line of Table 1, the corresponding critical speeds for a beam on an elastic foundation are presented. The gathered critical speeds of beams on elastic foundations are much greater than the ones of a simply-supported beam, while it is impossible for one to achieve such values of speed for this kind of beam and for normal soil types.

Let there be consideration of, for example, the case of a 2 m thick swampy layer of soil with Es = 0.005 × 108 N/m2. The corresponding Winkler constant is: k = 0.004 × 108. It is assumed that a very thin and feeble concrete beam with cross-section A = 0.125 m2 and EI = 0.20 × 107 N m2 is based on this kind of soil. The corresponding critical speed is 285 km/h. The above speed is close to the one of a landing jet, which, of course, is meaningless from a practical point of view.

sec.title: 5.2. The beam on elastic foundation
sec.p: Keeping in mind that it is impossible for the critical speed on a beam on an elastic foundation to be achieved, therefore the relations (20), (22) and (23) for subcritical speeds were applied.

The plots in Figures 6 and 8 show the deflections under point A for a beam with intermediate stiffness resting on a normal soil, with and without damping. The plots in Figures 7 and 9 show the deflections under point A of a low stiffness beam resting on a rather feeble soil, with and without damping. Finally, the plots in Figure 10 show the deflections of a normal beam with damping resting on a regular soil, for a range of subcritical speeds. Figure 6.
Point A deflections according to the proposed equations (——) and the Frýba relations (- - -) for speeds (in km/h): (a) 50, (b) 100, (c) 200 and (d) 300 km/h, for EI = 200 × 107, m = 30, k = 0.2 × 108, and β = 0. Figure 7.
Point A deflections according to the proposed equations (——) and the Frýba relations (- - -) for speeds (in km/h): (a) 50, (b) 100, (c) 200 and (d) 300 km/h, for EI = 0.2 × 107, m = 30, and k = 0.04 × 108, and β = 0. Figure 8.
Point A deflections according to the proposed equations (——) and the Frýba relations (- - -) for speeds (in km/h): (a) 50, (b) 100, (c) 200 and (d) 300 km/h, for EI = 200 × 107, m = 30, k = 0.2 × 108, and β = 1. Figure 9.
Point A deflections according to the proposed equations (——) and the Frýba relations (- - -) for speeds (in km/h): (a) 50, (b) 100, (c) 200 and (d) 300 km/h, for EI = 0.2 × 107, m = 30, and k = 0.04 × 108, and β = 1. Figure 10.
Point A deflections according to the proposed equations for E I = 20 × 107, m = 120, k = 0.04 × 108 and β = 1 and speeds: (——) 500 km/h, (— —) 350 km/h, (- - - -) 200 km/h, and (………) 50 km/h.

The deviations from Frýba’s results are mainly due to the number of terms kept in equation (19). The kept terms are three, but as Frýba (1972) quotes in his book, for very high speeds a big number of terms should be kept.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p:
From the preceding analysis, the following conclusions can be drawn:
For normal civil engineering constructions and a proper design, it is impossible for one to achieve the critical speeds (Table 1), since they are significantly higher than the ones of the corresponding free single-span simply-supported beam, even on cohesionless soils.
The proposed formulae are accurate for subcritical speeds either with or without damping. This accuracy is significant for normal and well-designed beams even when they are founded on cohesionless soils (Figures 6, 7 and 8), but it decreases for feeble beams on cohesionless soils as the critical speed is approached (Figure 9).
The Frýba formulae and the obtained corresponding diagrams show that point A does not continue to oscillate as the moving load passes beyond the half of the equivalent length, whereas in Figure 10, it can be seen that point A continues to oscillate with a rather significant free vibration response.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

FrýbaL (1972) Vibration of Solid and Structures under Moving Loads. Groningen: The Netherlands: Noordhoff Publishing.
FrýbaLNakagiriSYoshikawaN (1993) Stochastic finite elements for a beam on a random foundation with uncertain damping under a moving force. Journal of Sound and Vibration 163(1): 31–45.

GoloskokovEGFilippovAP (1962) Steady-state vibrations of beams on elastic foundation under the action of load moving in constant speed, [in Russian]. Trudy Laboratorii Gigravlicheskikh Mashin AN USSR 10: 19–26.
KenneyJT (1954) Steady-state vibrations of beams on elastic foundation for moving load. Journal of Applied Mechanics 4: 359–364.
MallikAKSarveshCAvinashSB (2006) Steady-state response of an elastically supported infinite beam to a moving load. Journal of Sound and Vibration 291: 1148–1169.
MathewsPM (1959) Vibration of a beam on elastic foundation I & II. Zeitschrift für Angewandte Mathematik und Mechanik 39(1/2): 13–19.

ref.citation: SteeleCR (1967) The finite beam with a moving load. Journal of Applied Mechanics 34(1): 111–118.
SunL (2001) Dynamic displacement response of beam-type structures to moving line loads. International Journal of Solids and Structures 38: 8869–8878.

citation.comment: Timoshenko SP (1926) Statical and dynamical stresses in rails. In Proceedings of International Congress Applied Mechanics, 21–23 August, Zürich, Switzerland, pp. 9–12
